5 #ifndef KASPER_RYDBERGFERENC_H
6 #define KASPER_RYDBERGFERENC_H
7 
8 #define nMAX 8000
9 
10 #include "KField.h"
11 /*
12  Test computations:
13 
14  1. Comparison of RadInt2Gordon with RadInt2Num; the latter computes the
15  integral of RadialH(n,l,r)*RadialH(np,lp,r)*r*r*r (eq. 63.1, page 262 in the Bethe-Salpeter book)
16  by numerical integration. See the files HydrogenAtomNumint.cc and QuadGaussLegendre.cc.
17  Note: for very small values of RadInt2Gordon ( below 10^-15) , these two values disagree. Nevertheless, further
18  checks (see below) show that the numerical integration values RadInt2Num are wrong in these cases, and the
19  RadInt2Gordon values are reliable also in these special cases.
20  In these cases the transition rates are extremely small, i.e. they can be taken as zero.
21 
22  2. Comparison with eqs. 63.4, 63.5, 61.7 and table 13 (pages 262-264, 257) in the Bethe-Salpeter book.
23 
24  3. Comparison with eqs. 68 and 66 in:
25  D. Dewangan, Phys. Reports 511 (2012) 1.
26 
27  4. Comparison with eq. 21 in Dewangan 2012 paper, and eqs. 2.23-2.27 in:
28  P. Storey, D. Hummer: Comp. Phys. Comm. 66 (1991) 129,
29  and eqs. 52-53 in:
30  J. D. Hey, J. Phys. B 39 (2006) 2641,
31  and eq. C2 in:
32  J. Watson, J. Phys. B 39 (2006) 1889.
33 
34 
35  5. Comparison with table 1 in:
36  D. Hoang-Binh, Comp. Phys. Commun. 166 (2005) 191.
37 
38  6. Comparison with the semiclassical spontaneous decay lifetime formula in the abstract
39  and with the lifetime values of table 1 in:
40  H. Marxer, L. Spruch, Phys. Rev. A 43 (1991) 1268
41 
42  7. Comparison with the spontaneous decay and BBR induced emission and absorption
43  approximative formulas of Glukhov et al., J. Phys. B 43 (2010) 125002.
44 
45 */
46
